title: Food Safety: Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP) in the Food Industry
headline: In this free online course, learn about the necessary practices to produce hygienic food within your food establishment.
description: This free online course will teach you about the key food safety requirements and practices to ensure the production of safe food in your establishment, known as GMP or good manufacturing practices. It covers topics ranging from the reception of raw materials to the production of the end product. It also covers establishment design, personal practices, production operations control and conditions, and food product information.
courseDescription:
Food safety and hygiene have become one of the utmost concerns for both consumers and food producers. Production of safe food is now the priority of food manufacturers. In this free online course on good manufacturing practices (GMP) in the food industry, you will learn in depth about the requirements for any production facility to produce safe and wholesome food that complies with the recommended global practice. The course starts with the introduction, definition and the importance of food safety and food production chain approach, and the need to comply with the global scientific recommendations to guarantee the safe production and processing or handling of food in all the segments of this chain. Moreover, learners will study the position of GMP in this chain and its importance as a key prerequisite program for the further application of hazard analysis and critical control points (HACCP) systems. Key food safety and GMP terms are also explained in this course.

Learners will study the requirements of any food processing establishment with regard to its location, design and equipment along with cleaning, disinfection, pest control and maintenance programs. The course will elaborate on the good hygienic practices that should be implemented by food processing personnel which include different hygiene aspects such as personal cleanliness, food-borne illnesses and proper food handling behaviors. Training and competence of food production personnel to properly implement the food safety requirements will be discussed. Significance of food processing steps and operations, the necessary control measures to control the safety of food and to prevent the cross-contamination during processing and other handling steps such as transportation will also be explained. Finally, learners will study the importance of proper food product labeling and the basic information that has to be shown on food packs or containers to create consumer awareness about the food they are about to consume.

Thus, this course will be relevant to those interested in the safety and hygiene of food, and to all establishments working in the different areas of food processing. Managers, supervisors, technicians, caterers or workers in any food manufacturing establishment will gain the required knowledge to ensure the production and handling of safe food within their establishment. This will also help them further implement any food safety management system standard such as ISO 22000 or BRC. Moreover, this course will help you advance in your career and show your competence in this area. Compliance with the global food safety requirements that will be reviewed in this course will be a great asset to any food establishment to keep its position within national and international food production and trade markets. No registration or subscription fees are charged so enrol today.

Start Course Now

slides:
• Food Safety and the Food Chain - Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module, you will be able to: 
    • Define what “food safety” is, and its importance.
    • Classify food safety hazards into their four categories.
    • Explain the food supply chain and its role in the safety of food.
    • Recognize the food contamination routes within food production chain.
    • Define what Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP) are and their significance to the safety of processed foods.
    • Explain the key terms and definitions that are widely used in the discipline of food safety in general, and GMP in particular.

  •  Food Safety and Food Chain - Lesson Summary

    • Food safety is the “assurance that food will not cause any adverse health effect to the consumer when it is prepared and/or eaten according to its intended use”.
    • Food safety is of utmost importance and priority both for ethical and economic reasons.
    • There are four main categories of food safety hazards: biological, chemical, physical and allergens.
    • Food production chain is the sequence of steps and stages food undergoes from the primary production until reaching the end consumer.
    • The main stages of food supply chain are: primary production, processing, distribution and preparation.
    • In any of these stages, food can be contaminated by a contaminant through different routes.
    • Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP) are “the procedures or international measures which provide the proper environmental conditions and a management system necessary for the production of safe and wholesome foods”.
    • GMPs are of the key prerequisite programs for the application of HACCP system.

  • Establishment: Requirements - Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Identify what are the location, design and layout requirements for a food establishment to ensure the safety of food.
    • Recognize the specifications of the materials used in constructing a food establishment.
    • Explain the necessary personal hygiene facility specifications within food establishments.
    • Recognize ventilation, water supply, lighting and storage requirements to ensure the production of safe food.
    • Distinguish between cleaning and disinfection of a food establishment and their importance.
    • Explain the importance of pest control within a food production establishment.

  • Establishment: Requirements - Lesson Summary

    • Location of a food establishment should be chosen carefully to prevent food from being contaminated.

    • The design and layout of a food establishment should facilitate the maintenance, cleaning and disinfection of the building and equipment.

    • Durable materials have to be used in building the structures in food establishments. These materials should be easily maintained, cleaned and when necessary disinfected.

    • The design, construction and arrangement of drain facilities must be able to avoid the risk of contamination of materials or products.

    • Sufficient and appropriately designated facilities should be provided to clean food processing utensils and equipment.

    • Attention should be paid to the type and location of personal hygiene facilities.

    • There should be sufficient facilities to perform the required heat/cooling treatments of food such as chilling, freezing, cooking and heating.

    • Attention should be paid to the type and location of personal hygiene facilities.

    • There should be sufficient facilities to perform the required heat/cooling treatments of food such as chilling, freezing, cooking and heating.

  • Food Processing Personnel - Learning Outcomes

  • On completion of this module you will be able to: 

    • Describe the contribution of personnel health status to the safety of foods.  

    • List the symptoms of food-borne illnesses that require the temporary exclusion of food workers.

    • Explain the requirements of personal hygiene and the recommended behaviors.

    • Discuss the importance of personnel training and competence within food establishments.

    • Recognize the necessity of training programs verification and updating.

  • Food Processing Personnel - Lesson Summary

    • It should be ensured that people who come in direct or indirect contact of food are not likely to contaminate food.

    • Persons who work in food processing or handling are required to undergo medical examination before being employed or involved in any food related activity.

    • There are a number of symptoms that have to be reported to the management which include: diarrhea, vomiting, jaundice, discharge from the eyes, ears or nose, fever, sore throat with fever, and skin lesions (like boils, sores, cuts, burn, etc.).

    • Food handlers within the food establishment must maintain the highest and degree of personal cleanliness. This can be achieved through wearing the proper and protective clothing to prevent the contamination of food.

      Food workers should be aware of the proper hand washing procedure.

    • All visitors, maintenance workers or contractors have to comply with and adhere to the requirements of food safety set by the establishment.

    • Training is an essential requirement for any food establishment that seeks to create a strong food safety system and to promote the competence of food personnel.

  • Operations and Information - Learning Outcomes

  • On completion of this module, you will be able to:

    • Describe the importance of food processing operations control.

    • Explain how to construct a flow chart and product description of a food product.

    • Identify control parameters for different food processing steps.

    • Explain the difference between correction and corrective actions.

    • Discuss the necessary corrections and corrective actions in case of any product non-compliance.

    • Identify the importance of traceability in ensuring the safety of foods.

    • Explain the significance of labeling and product information, and what are the mandatory information that have to be shown on the label.

  • Operations and Information - Lesson summary

    • Control of food production operations within the food establishment is a key factor in ensuring the production of safe and suitable food.

    • All food products produced by a food establishment should have clear, precise and adequate description.

    • It is very important to the food establishment to construct a flow diagram to describe the steps used in the production of food along with their correct sequence and interaction points.

    • A food establishment should conduct a planned sequence of observations or measurements of control parameters to assess whether production steps or hygienic measures are under control or not.

    • A corrective action is an in-depth procedure that must be taken to identify and correct the root cause of the problem (Root Cause Analysis, RCA).

    • All raw materials should be purchased from registered suppliers, and to be assessed against a defined criteria and specifications.

    • Food establishment should pay great attention to prevent or minimize any source of contamination from reaching to foods. The sources of contamination varies from the raw materials, improper practices, inadequate hygiene, improper processing, to the end storage and dispatch stages.
